em.strong: Yancey County Schools strive to provide a safe and nurturing environment to empower all students to achieve their full potential as life-long learners and global citizens.

div.style: background-size: cover; background-position: center center; background-image: url(https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/bXAo5m5SI0urPaor5oanND-XrgiMCQsWHaO7asnKpEFx0GtasHw0Sap_uh0wlY4PCH5s8j_QZw=w16383);

div.p: Click here to access the new Parent & Family FAQ webpage which was added to the COVID-19 Response & Resources website. New questions will be added to this page as they are received and vetted for accuracy.

The new page also allows parents and families the opportunity to view a video series with our own Deputy State Superintendents Bev Emory and David Stegall responding to some of the most frequently asked questions. These videos are released through social media daily between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. A special thanks to Elaine Darby, NCDPI Web Marketing Specialist for leading this project!

p.strong: Will My High School Senior Graduate This Spring?

div.p: How the statewide school closure due to COVID-19 will impact seniors scheduled to graduate this spring. https://youtu.be/lc2QoyVx9dw

p.strong: Where Can Teachers and Parents Find Online Instructional Resources?

div.p: Guidance on where to find online resources to help teachers and parents provide instruction to students.

p.strong: Does My Child Have to Complete the Work Assigned by the School?

div.p: Discussion on why it's important for students to complete school work assigned by teachers. https://youtu.be/zG-2D2BBz_U

p.strong: What Do I Do If I Don’t Have a Computer or Internet Access?

div.p: Options for families who don’t have online access, guidance on who to ask for assistance and a discussion about innovative and creative ways school and community organizations are working together to bring computers and internet access to families. https://youtu.be/Wu2FfcCQgn4

p.strong: How Do I Find Locations in My Area That are Serving School Meals?

div.p: Resources to help parents find locations across the state that are serving school meals. https://youtu.be/n9tppeMIagk

p.strong: When Will Students Return to School? How Will That Decision Be Made?

div.p: Discussion of date students may return to school and the process state education leaders used to determine that date. https://youtu.be/TCFsN8QR6NY

p.strong: How Will My Children Be Graded and Can They Still Pass Their Grades?

div.p: Discussion on how grading will shift emphasis for the remainder of the year to supporting student progress and communicating feedback to students and their families. https://youtu.be/8lXLXZCOmLA

p.strong: What Will Happen to End of Grade Tests?

div.p: Updates on actions taken by NCDPI and the State Board of Education for year-end assessments for the 2019-20 school year. https://youtu.be/hSA6AaJBRRM

p.strong: Where Can I Find Childcare Options If I Must Report to Work?

div.p: Options for childcare for those who must report to work. Priority will be given to frontline healthcare workers, emergency service workers and other vital services workers in our communities. https://youtu.be/Wg4z1rbTIoA

p.strong: How Can I Find Support for My Child Who Has an IEP?

div.p: Guidance on how schools, districts and the state will support parents with children who have Individualized Learning Plans (IEP) https://youtu.be/kScawDJNcNc

a.aria-label: Google Forms, YCS School Nutrition Survey

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-OwsYgb jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque GNzUNc

div.p: Parent/Guardian,
We can provide breakfast and lunch for all children age 18 and under.
Our distribution centers are: Blue Ridge Elementary School (828-682-8150) and East Yancey Middle School (828- 682-2281).
Please call if you have questions or need to be added to the list. If you have not completed the School Nutrition survey, please do so.

Learning packets, books and devices can be delivered on the buses if needed. Please call your your child's school if he/she needs more resources for educational needs. Teachers will be calling two times a week to check on the students and their needs.
A couple of educational TV Sources are: UNC TV and PBS also...

div.p: Yancey County Schools Launches “Say Something” Anonymous Reporting System

On March 5, 2020, Yancey County Schools is officially launching the “Say Something” Anonymous Reporting System (SS-ARS) for students, which most North Carolina public school districts will be adopting this year to meet the reporting guidelines and standards developed by the N.C. Department of Public Instruction and the Center for Safer Schools.
Select the link above for more information.

h3.div: Yancey County Schools Response to Coronavirus (COVID-19)

div.p: For Immediate Release Yancey County Schools Response to Coronavirus (COVID-19) March 4, 2020
Families,

With ongoing concerns over the Coronavirus (COVID-19), we want to share information about the measures Yancey County Schools practice to guard against this, and many other communicable diseases that are so prevalent this time of year.

YCS Administration and School Nurses are working closely with the Yancey County Health Department to continually monitor information provided by the local, state, and federal levels as well as the vast amount of information available from the CDC website. YCS will continue to diligently follow local, state, and federal health guidelines regarding appropriate protocol for any health-related concerns.
Select link above for more information

h3.div: Charter to Offer Free Access to Spectrum Broadband and Wi-Fi For 60 Days For New K-12 and College Student Households and More

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;
touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: Charter Communications has announced that they will extend 60 days of free Spectrum Internet access at 100mb/s to all new customers in households with K-12 or higher education students starting on Monday, March 16th, 2020. Additionally, as part of the FCC's Keep Americans Connected Pledge, they will temporarily open their nationwide public Wi-Fi hotspots to provide free Internet access. To sign up for free Internet access, Spectrum has set up a hotline at 1-844-488-8395.

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-uQSCkd jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque GNzUNc

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: You may complete the YCS Home Access to Internet Survey online; select the form below. If you prefer, a paper copy will come home with your student on Friday, March 13. See the parent informational letter below . Please complete the survey and the Student and Parent Signature form and return to school by Monday, March 16th. MHHS students and parents already have signatures on file.

iframe.aria-label: Drive, Informational Letter_Dear Yancey County Schools Parent with logo.docx

div.aria-label: Drive, Informational Letter_Dear Yancey County Schools Parent with logo.docx

img.span: Informational Letter_Dear Yancey County Schools Parent with logo.docx

div.p: In preparation for potential school closures, we want to share information regarding digital resources and access.

h3.div: In mid-March, homes across the country will begin receiving invitations to complete the 2020 Census. Once the invitation arrives, you should respond for your home in one of three ways: online, by phone, or by mail.

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: The 2020 Census will determine congressional representation, inform hundreds of billions in federal funding, and provide data that will impact communities for the next decade.

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;
touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: School lunches. Plans for highways. Support for firefighters and families in need. Census results affect your community every day.

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;
touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: The 2020 Census count impacts the federal funds that communities receive each year for programs and services that are critical for schools, students, and younger children, such as:

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: Special education, Head Start, after-school programs, and classroom technology.

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

h3.div: Food assistance, including free and reduced-price school lunches.

In compliance with federal laws, the Yancey County School System administers all educational programs, employment activities and admissions without discrimination because of race, religion, national or ethnic origin, color, age, military service, disability, or gender, except where exemption is appropriate and allowed by law. Yancey County Schools is in the process of reviewing its website to ensure compliance with Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act.
